content: BLOCK GRANT OPTIONS. State Options for receiving funding include State block grant, Local block grant, or Federal statute options. Applicable Funding refers to all funds appropriated for the Department of Education. The curr_chunk discusses the definition of "funding" as all funds appropriated for the Department of Education for specific programs or activities under various laws. SEC. 2. BLOCK GRANTS. From the total applicable funding, the Secretary may allot funds to States based on the number of individuals aged 5 through 17, and to local educational agencies based on the number of individuals in the school district served by the agency in that age group. The Secretary determines the number of children aged 5 through 17 for each academic year based on the most recent data available. States can reserve up to 1 percent of allotted funds for administrative costs. Each local educational agency receiving funds under this Act may reserve up to 2 percent for administration costs. In States choosing the State block grant option, unreserved funds are allocated for students in public or private schools. In States selecting the local block grant option, funds allotted under subsection (a)(2) not reserved shall be available for students enrolled in public or private elementary or secondary schools. The amount allotted for each student will be adjusted accordingly. Each public school receiving assistance under this Act must use it for qualified education expenses. Parents or guardians of private school students receiving assistance should use it for the costs of attending the private school. Each parent or guardian of a home school student receiving assistance under this Act must use it for qualified elementary and secondary education expenses. State or local educational agencies should adjust the amount awarded for students to account for high-need students and different costs of living in urban and rural areas. The Secretary may allocate remaining funding to State and local recipients under specific laws for States opting for the described option. Funding reductions will be equal for States choosing the option. Accountability measures are outlined in Section 4. Each entity receiving assistance under this Act must use funds to supplement, involve parents and the public in planning, and submit reports on fund distribution and impact on student achievement. Reports must be made available to parents and the public. Each State or local educational agency must include information on student achievement with respect to challenging content or performance standards in the report available to parents and the public. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. The term "local educational agency" is defined in section 14101 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. "Qualified elementary and secondary education expenses" include tuition, fees, academic tutoring, special needs services, books, supplies, computer equipment, room and board, uniforms, and other equipment related to a student's enrollment or attendance at a school. Expenses for room and board, uniforms, transportation, and supplementary items required by a school for enrollment. Homeschooling expenses included if meeting state or local laws. "School" defined as providing kindergarten, elementary, or secondary education. "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education. The term "State" includes all states of the United States, as well as territories and other jurisdictions.
